I have been doing work for the prisoner for some tune; he is a cab proprietor and cornchandler—it was somewhere about the end of January that this cab came to me—I knew that it had been injured in an accident—he did not tell me he was going to make a claim against the company—he said I was not to begin on the repairs of the cab till somebody came from the company to look at it—they always do send somebody—he did not tell me he was going to make a claim against the company, and pay me something on account of the job—I think the cab remained on my premises about three weeks, till 8th February, when it went out—he paid me £5 on the 6th February, and another £5 on the 13th—that was for work done previous to this—I gave him a receipt for it in a book, not showing who the work was done for—he gave me another pound in March, before the £2 10s.—I made out the £13 bill to get my money—he would not pay me unless I did it; I had to do it; I believed it was going to be shown to the

company—I did not know it was to show that he had paid me £13—I did not know what it was to be used for—I did not know that he had taken action against the company—of course, I suppose it was to show to the company—I did not communicate to the company until I found they were going to inquire into the damage—before that I had seen a man named Myers—I see him every day—I believe Myers and the prisoner had been on bad terms for along time—Myers keeps a furniture shop next door to Skinner in Clapham Road—I did not discuss with Myers what I should do with regard to this; I did not talk it over with him or mention it to him; I never had any conversation with him about it, not till after the company came and saw me. (The witness's deposition, being referred to, stated: "I had four or five conversations about the £18 bill with Myers")—I don't think I spoke about it till after I had been to the company—I don't recollect saying that—I believe Leftwich was in Skinner's employ—I don't know that he was; I saw him there—he was in his employment when he kept the baker's shop; whether he was in the corn shop I don't know—I saw him in the shop when I was paid this bill; I did not ask him if he had left, I did not say anything at the Police-court about the boy and the two stamps; I don't know who the boy was—I could not speak about it before the Magistrate, they would not let me; I have seen Leftwich every day since these proceedings have been pending—I have not talked to him about the boy.

Re-examined, Whenever the prisoner paid me money I signed my book for it—he kept the book, and I signed for all the money he paid me (book produced)—this is the book—part of it is my writing, the other part is Leftwich's—the latter part shows small sums paid week by week, every Saturday (Entries were read of £5 on account on 13th February, and £3 on 20th February)—he never during this year paid me £11 10s. in cash; I never received more than £4 in cash of him in my life; if he paid me more than £4 it was by cheque—these sums of £5 were by cheque—there is no receipt in this book for the £2 10s. cheque or the £1, because that was to be left, and scratched out of my book; that was the only bill he had since 1890—I had not delivered to him any separate account for any particular work, since September, 1890—all the payments in this book were made to me on account of the general balance that was owing—Myers had nothing to do with the writing of the latter; I said so at the Police-court.

By the COURT. The entry of the £2 10s. and £1 was struck out of the book; this is it; it was brought forward on every page up to the time I worked for him; I mean it was to be left out, so that it should not be in his bill—I refer to that in a bracket.

JAMES LEFTWICH . I live at 16, Clarence Road, Hackney—at the beginning of this year I was in the prisoner's service as manager, at his shop at 128, Clapham Road—I heard there had been an accident to a cabin January—I remember on a Saturday, towards the end of March or beginning of April, Alexander coming to the prisoner's shop in the Clapham Road, and Alexander and Skinner had an altercation about a bill, and Alexander went away and came back, and soon afterwards Skinner told me to pass the pen and ink to Alexander; I did so, and Alexander came to the counter and signed two bills, one of which is in front of me, and was for £3 10s.; the other was a little way at the side, and I cannot

say whether it was for £13, or £13 10s.—the £3 10s. bill was signed first—all that took place between the signing of the first and second bill was the payment of a penny for a stamp—Alexander paid for one stamp and the prisoner for the other, and a boy was sent for them—when the bills were signed they were receipted—I saw a cheque given by the prisoner to Alexander after the bills were signed—I saw no cash pass from the prisoner to Alexander—I heard of the action against the railway company being tried at the County-court—before that I was asked by Alexander to ask the prisoner what he had done with the £3 10s. bill—I did so, and the prisoner said he had thrown it on the b———fire—I saw the prisoner after his return from the trial of the action, on the same day—he told me that he had got over the case, but they had impounded the bill, and Mr. Alexander, or Alexander, had got a witness—I said I was the witness—the prisoner said he should sue Alexander for £1,000 for slander, and should be sure to win—when I said I was the witness, he said I need not say anything about the bills; that Mr. Alexander was in the habit of coming and signing a number of bills in the shop; I said I should not commit perjury—this letter is in my writing—I wrote it in consequence of an arrangement with Alexander.

Cross-examined. I had been about two years, I should think, in the prisoner's employment; during that time Alexander, I believe, had been doing work for the prisoner—I had seen him a number of times—I left the prisoner's employment about two months now I should think—J am in employment now—I was not in the prisoner's employment when I was examined at the Police-court, I might have left him about a fortnight before, so that I should have left him some time in July—we had had no differences and were not on unfriendly terms up to the time of the letter, we were the best of friends—I thought this was a very dishonest transaction, and I wrote the letter for Mr. Alexander—I continued in the prisoner's employment after having written the letter, and after the action had been heard, until I found another house to go to.
Re-examined. I did not write this letter in consequence of any quarrel with the prisoner.

JOHN ALEXANDER, JUN . I am Alexander's son, and assist him in his wheelwright's business—I remember the prisoner's cab, No. 10, being brought for repairs about the end of January—I and my fellow servants worked on it—we put no new shafts to the cab—the entry in my father's book correctly represents the work that was actually done—the fair cost of those repairs would be about £3 10s.

CHARLES HEAD . I am a coachbuilder, of 3, Gloucester Road, Kensington—on the 5th May this year I and Hope inspected a hansom cab on behalf of the South-Western Railway Company, to see what repairs had been done—the prisoner was there—I called the prisoner's attention to a shaft which had been broken and spliced up afterwards—he said the shafts had met with an accident since new ones were put—I examined the shafts, and I can say that neither of them had been new within the preceding four months—I put the cost of such repairs as I saw at about £5 at the outside—that is what I should charge.
GUILTY .

hi.rs: A witness deposed to the prisoner's good character.—Four Months' Hard Labour.

div1.p:
887.
HARRY HAYWOOD (34)
, Unlawfully assaulting
Florence Lacey, and occasioning her actual bodily harm.
After MR. AVORY had opened the case, the prisoner stated, in the hearing of the JURY, that he was guilty, and the JURY thereupon found him

GUILTY
Judgment respited.
.

p.hi:
There was another indictment against the prisoner
for feloniously casting lime at
Florence Lacey with intent to do her grievous bodily harm. No evidence was offered by the prosecution.

div1.p:
—
NOT GUILTY —

888.
WILLIAM TAYLOR (20) and
CHARLES JONES (18)
PLEADED GUILTY to burglary in the dwelling-house of
Ernest Hopkins Ham, and stealing a basket of plate and other articles.

TAYLOE also PLEADED GUILTY** to a conviction of felony in May, 1888, in the name of John Dale; and JONES** to one in July, 1891.—
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour each.

889.
ALEXANDER JOHN MILTON (33)
, Unlawfully and carnally knowing
Emily Furnival, aged fourteen years.
NOT GUILTY .

890.
GEORGE PRICE (28) and
JAMES SAUNDERS (29)
, Unlawfully attempting to commit burglary in the dwelling-house of
Robert Hawker Poynder.

SAUNDERS
PLEADED GUILTY .

ROBERT HAWKER POYNDER . I am a clerk, living at Lockwood, Anerley—a few minutes after one a.m. on August 8th I heard a window opened—I looked out and saw a man standing on the doorsteps—I asked him what he was doing there—he made no reply—I shouted and blew a whistle, and he ran away to a garden nearly opposite diagonally—I then saw another man emerge from the shade of a bay window and run in the same direction and then hide himself under the wall—in a few minutes a constable came to whom I made a statement—he and I examined the window and found it was half open—I gave a description of one man—I could not swear from his features if Price was the man, but from his apparel I could—he had on a light-coloured pair of corduroy or fustian trousers, a dark coat and a soft cloth cap with a peak—there is a lamp not quite in front of my house, but a little diagonally—I could not identify the other man—I only saw one shoulder and hw hat—I identified Price directly I saw him after his arrest by his dress.
ELIZABETH HALL . I am the prosecutor's housekeeper—on this night I saw that this window was closed and I fastened it.

THOMAS COLLYER (Police Constable). On the morning of 8th August I heard a whistle—the prosecutor made a communication to me—after searching for about a quarter of an hour I found in a field about a 100 yards from the prosecutor's house the two prisoners in a shed, pretending to be asleep—the prosecutor had given a description—I blew my whistle, and another constable came—Price said he knew

nothing; he went into the shed to have a night's sleep—I took them to the station, and then went for the prosecutor, who came and identified Price as the man he saw standing at the top of his area steps—Price said, "You are wrong this time, old man."
Price in his defence said he know nothing of the affair; that he went into the shed to sleep and was arrested,

GUILTY —
Twelve Months' Hard Labour each (Set page 1349).

891.
EDWIN JOHNS (32) and
HINES (20)
, Robbery with violence on
John Frater, and stealing a watch from his person. Second Count, receiving the same.

JOHN FRATER . I live at 44, Stangate Street—on Saturday, 16th July, I was coming out of my house about half-past eleven—the two prisoners, whom I had never seen before, were outside the Duke's Arms public-house, just across the road—they rushed at me with their hands across me, and took my watch from my pocket, off the chain—I did not see them take it, but I missed it as I was going into the Duke's Arms—I went back and asked the prisoners to give me my watch back, and Hines knocked me down and kicked me—I cannot say if Johns did anything—they let go of me; I got up and ran after Hines, who ran round into the public-house and then out of the corner I had Just passed—I saw no more of them till the next Thursday night at the Police station, when I identified Hines—I was unable to identify Johns.

Cross-examined. My watch was stolen as I had my foot on the kerb by two men tumbling against me, as if larking I did not discover my loss till I got into the public-house—the robbery was done very quickly—I came out and went after the two men, who were just across the road, and I was knocked down—I went to the station, and afterwards went to the Duke's Arms with the constable, but it was closed—when I said in the public-house that I had lost my watch some of the customers, it might have been six, came to the door, and saw me go after the two thieves—next day, Sunday, I went to the Duke's Arms, I identified no one there then—I did not point out Tug Wilson and say I believed he was one of the thieves—I did not point out anyone and find out afterwards it was a mistake—I was taken to the station to identify on 19th July—I am certain the prisoners are the thieves—I said before the Magistrate, in answer to Johns, "I did not recognise you exactly; I am not perfectly certain about you now"—I could not recognise him—I am certain he is the man, because a party saw him while I was on the ground; I say he is the man, not from my own recollection, but from what other people have told me.

WILLIAM DONOHUE . I am potman at the Duke's Arms, 27, Upper Marsh, Lambeth—on Saturday night, 16th July, after Johns left our house, I heard a cry of "Stop thief!"—I came out immediately, followed by the landlord, and saw the prosecutor in the road, with Johns in the act of kicking him—I am positive it was Johns, because I had had to put him out previously; I could see him quite plainly; it was eleven o'clock when they came in, and half-past eleven when the cry of "Stop thief!" was raised—there are two big lamps outside and a lamp-post opposite, and other two lamps about 150 yards down the street where

they ran—the prisoner was between the two lights and the lamp-post in the middle of the road—after Johns kicked the prosecutor, a man said something to Johns, and they made off, one down one street, and one down another; I followed, but lost them—I afterwards went with the prosecutor to Kennington Road Police-station to report the loss to the Inspector—on the following Tuesday night I was called to the station, and immediately identified Hines from among twelve or thirteen others—afterwards I went again to the station, and identified at once Johns out of twelve or thirteen men—I am positive about him.

Cross-examined. I have been at the Duke's Arms about three months; I have given evidence a number of times; I have frequently done so against thieves in cases where Record was the officer—I have never been charged—I have been a material witness in about twenty-five cases—I have been behind the bar now for about six years—I only know Tug Wilson by name; he may have been at the Duke's Arms on the Sunday after this robbery; I could not swear—I do not know that anybody suggested one of the thieves was in the bar on the Sunday afternoon—on the Saturday evening after the prosecutor went out after the thieves, half a dozen customers came to the door—Johns had followed Hines into the house, and they made a snatch at a lady's locket, and we had to put him out—the lady would not charge him—I don't know if Johns had been in the house since nine o'clock—I don't know if he lives a few doors off; he has so many names and addresses—I knew him by sight—I did not see him actually kick the prosecutor; his foot was raised, and the prosecutor was on the ground—when I came back to the house after closing, the prisoner Johns was not in the public-house—he did not wish me goodnight—I went from the public-house to the station, and was there at closing-time—I did not see Johns next day at our public-house, but I am not always in the bar.

Re-examined. I have been taking situations as potman for about four years, and bad characters make it a habit to come into public-houses—on the 2nd of August about fourteen of the prisoners' friends came and blacked my eyes, and stabbed me.

SAMUEL MASON . I keep the Duke's Arms public-house—on Saturday night, 16th July, I was standing at the door and saw a scuffle—I only saw Hines run at the prosecutor, who fell over—I did not see Johns over the prosecutor—I cannot say what took place—afterwards, at closing-time, I saw Johns.

Cross-examined. I saw Johns in the house shortly before closing-time; he wished me good-night—Donohue had gone to the station then several customers went to the door when the prosecutor complained of losing his watch, and went out—I had known Johns as a customer for about a fortnight previous—I had seen him in my house earlier that evening—I am not aware that he was treating some women—I did not see Mrs. Smith there—I was at the further end of my long bar—they might have been there without my seeing them—I did not see Johns at my house; he might have been there—Tug Wilson was there on Saturday and Sunday—I cannot say if the prosecutor was also there on Sunday.

ALICE BATCHELOR . I am the wife of William Batchelor, a miller; we live at 44, Stangate Street—on this night, between a quarter and half-past eleven, I saw the prisoners coming from the Distillers public-house—

Johns passed something to Hines—the prosecutor came up and said to Johns, "You have got my watch"—he said, "I have not got it; he has got it," meaning Hines—the prosecutor said to Hines, "You have got my watch"—Hines said he had not—the prosecutor said. "Come to the top and see if I can see a policeman"—he went two or three yards, and then Hines hit him, twisted his leg, and threw him—the prosecutor is my landlord—I helped to pick him up—the men ran away.

Cross-examined. I saw the prisoners at the Police-court—this all took a very short time—I was about the length of this Court away—I had seen Johns before—I was not taken to the station to identify him—when I gave my evidence at the Police-court Johns at once suggested that I had made a mistake.
Re-examined. There was a good light, and I could see the men distinctly—I am sure the prisoners were the men.

FRANCES SMITH . I am the wife of Henry Smith, a painter, of 16, Griffin Street—on this night, at 11.30,1 saw the prisoners come out of the Distillers public-house, and Johns passed something to Hines—the prosecutor came up and said to Johns, "You have got my watch"—he laid, "I have not; go to the other man"—the prosecutor said to Hines, "You have got my watch"—he said, "I have not"—the prosecutor said, "Will you come to the top to the policeman, and be searched, and then Hines threw the prosecutor and kicked him, and he ran away, and I and Mrs. Batchelor took up the cry of "Stop thief!"—I had known Johns before by his wife doing our washing; I had not seen him very often—I could see him distinctly, and am sure of him.

Cross-examined. Before the robbery on this night Johns treated me to some drink in Mr. Mason's public-house, the Distillers, about a quarter past eleven—I was not in the house at closing-time—I had only spoken to Johns three or four times—I had been in the house before—I never said to Johns' wife that Johns had too much to say, and I would have my own back some day; nothing of the kind—I have always been on most friendly and kindly terms with the prisoner, and have no illwill towards him whatever.

JOHN WARD (Police Sergeant)—I arrested Johns; I told him the charge—he said "All right, I will go with you"—at the station he was placed with others, and picked out, after some hesitation, by the prosecutor, and without any hesitation by Mason and Donohue—in reply to the charge, he said "All right"—I got this watch from a man named Woodford, who bought it from Hines.

GUILTY. Strongly recommended to mercy by the
JURY.—
Discharged on recognisances.
HINES—
Twelve Months* Hard Labour.

892.
ARTHUR JOHN HEWLETT,
JOHN MILLS (19),
GEORGE MILLS (17), and
BETSY ANN COOLIDGE (40)
, Breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Thomas Jolliffe, and stealing a pair of trousers and other articles, his property.

ELIZABETH JOLLIFFE . I live with my husband at Amwell Hill, Wandsworth—on June 27th I left the house about 11.45, leaving no one in it—I shut the front door and the side door—I returned at 3.40 and opened the door with a latch-key, and found the chain up; I had not

left it so—I fetched a policeman, went to the side door, and found it broken open, and everything turned over—the door leading into the hall had been broken open—I missed things value £30 or £35; these trousers are my husband's; this silk handkerchief was taken from a coat pocket; this is a gold keyless watch and a gold pin—they are all my property—a gold brooch has not been found.

JOSEPH GOUGH (Policeman V). On the evening of 8th July I saw George Mills in Eldon Street, Wandsworth, outside his house—I told him I was a police officer, and should take him in custody for being concerned with his brother in breaking into several houses in Wandsworth—he said, "I don't know anything about housebreaking; I have been with my brother several times for a drive"—I found this handkerchief on him.

JOHN WINDSOR (Police Sergeant V). On July 8th I saw John Mills in Falcon Road, outside the Falcon public-house—I told him I should take him and charge him, with several others, with housebreaking—he said nothing—I went to his lodgings, 64, Eldingham Street, Wandsworth, and made inquiries—I searched an upstairs front room, and behind a picture hanging over the mantelpiece I found this silver chain, which Mrs. Jolliffe identifies—I also found this pawn-ticket and counterpane on the bed—Coolidge is the mother of the two Mills; they live in the same house.

JOHN THORLEY (Detective V). On 8th July I went with other officers to 64, Elkington Street, and assisted in searching the house—I was standing at the foot of the stairs with a large bundle of clothing, when George Mills came in and said, "Halloa, what is up?"—I said, "Who are you?"—he said, "I am George Mills"—I said, "Where do you sleep?"—he said, "In the front room upstairs. "

FREDERICK RUMBRIDGE (Police Sergeant). I was with the other officers—the prisoner George told me the female prisoner's room; I went there, and found 45 or 46 pawn-tickets in a box on the sideboard, one of which, marked £, is attached to the depositions; it relates to a pair of trousers pledged for 4s.—I arrested Coolidge that night, and told her the charge—she said she knew nothing about it.
Cross-examined by Coolidge. You did not tell me the things had been given to you to pledge.

PERCY PETERS . I am assistant to Mr. Chase, a pawnbroker, of 170, York Road, Battersea—I know Coolidge as a customer; I cannot say whether she pawned these trousers, but they were pawned for 4s. in the name of Ann Coolidge, and this ticket was given to the person.

WILLIAM PUGSLEY (Police Inspector V). On 12th July I had a warrant to search 48, College Street, Chelsea, a working jeweller's shop, and found Hewlett there; I asked him if he was the proprietor of the shop—he said, "Yes"—I said, "lama Police Inspector, and have a warrant to search this house, as you are suspected of receiving articles, and housebreaking—I asked him what watches he had; he showed me a number, and this watch among them—I asked him if he had any pins; he gave me a number, and I found among them this one—I sent for Mrs. Jolliffe, who identified them—I then asked him for an explanation—he said, "I bought them from a strange man about this day week; I paid £2 5s. for them; I don't know his name and address"; but ho gave me a description—I saw a number of pawnbrokers' lists in the shop—one was dated 11th July, and had this watch described; my search was

on the 12th—I asked him if he had made any entries in his books of the transaction—he said "No"—the watch was No. 2 on the list, and the number of it was given—I asked him about the list; he said he had not noticed it—I saw some silver (produced)—I have made a list of the articles: two silver salt spoons, three table spoons, six dessert, six tea, six forks, six dessert forks, sugar tongs and scoop, and a butter knife—you can see the remains of a crest on the sugar tongs, and the spoons all bear marks of the erasure of something—on further search some plated articles were found—this clock was going in the sitting-room; this sugar basin and milk jug were in use in the kitchen—this teapot was hanging in a cupboard—here are a number of knives and forks which are Miss Smith's—I saw Sergeant Windsor go to the back kitchen and produce from it this jemmy; I called the prisoner's attention to it.

Cross-examined by MR. GILL. Hewlett told me that he had recently bought the business, and I believe it is true—he has only been there since Christmas—he got married and bought the business—he was at the shop with his wife; he works at the bench himself, and he has a man and boy in a shop, behind, apparently repairing for the trade—Mr. Norman is his employer—the shop has been under suspicion—when the jemmy was found he said, "I bought this business some months ago; that must have been there at the time; I have never seen it before"—he told me there were the remains of melted metal there—I asked him to show me all the watches he had got, which he did—I saw this watch, and told him it had been stolen—he said he bought it of a man, who sold it across the counter, and described him; he said he had not noticed the list—he had the watch on the 27th, and this was July 12th—it was only in the day before's list; the list is sometimes one page; sometimes three or four; this was larger than usual—this was an ordinary gold watch, and nothing on the face of it to attract attention; it cost £5 10s.; I have seen the receipt; it was on the work-bench in the shop—there was cheap jewellery in the window, mostly chains, brooches, and bracelets—he produced the plate in his wife's presence, who said they were bought for her use—he said that a man called five or six weeks previously and brought some silver, weighing sixty or seventy ounces, and he paid £15 10s. for it—I said that they were stolen, and asked him for an explanation—he said, "I purchased them from a man who came to my shop a month or five weeks ago, and paid him £15 10s. in gold," and then he described the man—I made this note in his presence there and then—"he did not attempt to conceal anything—I saw some deeds relating to the property—I think this (produced) is the worst specimen of erasure from the goods—the silver is very old—I said, "As a tradesman you must see that the marks have been removed from these articles"—he said, "It appears so"—this fork is the worst, and (from another parcel) this one—I find the remains of a stag's head on these tongs, it has been scraped or filed away and re silvered—his wife said that the silver had been bought, and that they used it when their friends and relatives came—I took the name of the man John Waiter, who was working there, and of the boy, who was learning the trade, and I saw some books there, but only with regard to articles brought to be repaired.
By the JURY. He described the man who brought the watch and pin to five feet six inches high, complexion fair, fair moustache, dark

clothes, and bowler hat, and the man who brought the other articles as a gentlemanly-looking man five feet four or five inches, close-shaved, and dark suit of clothes and a dark hat—I do not know that it is required that a jeweller should keep books—the prisoner is licensed to deal in plate.

Re-examined. The wife's statement that the articles were purchased for her use related to the silver, which was in a box with a glass lid to it, with deeds relating to property and wearing apparel—the silver is described in this police list of May 16th—Hewlett had a file of these lists, but there were a number missing—there had been a furnace there.

By the COURT. We make up the lists and put the descriptions on them—here are on one list 138 articles—not one per cent, of those are reported by jewellers, but occasionally we get information—people can go into a public room and buy plate.

JOHN WINDSOR (Re-examined). I found the silver locked in a box in what was designated the kitchen; I asked for the key and removed some clothes, and found this box with a glass lid, and the silver in it.
GILL (Police Sergeant 8 B). It is part of my duty to deliver the police list to jewellers and pawnbrokers—I delivered one to the prisoner Hewlett on 16th May, the last of the date.
Cross-examined by MR. GILL. I delivered it about 9.30; I put it on the counter.

CHARLES SMITH (185 B). On 22nd and 23rd May I called at Hewlett's workshop and asked him if he had had any property offered for sale—I had a written list with me, and said, "Have you had any of these offered for sale? Some of them have bull's heads on them"—he read the list down, and said, "No. "
Cross-examined by MR. GILL. The list is destroyed—I knew Hewlett, and have been at his shop—Harwood had the shop before him; I never spoke to him.

THOMAS ANNEST . I am servant to Mr. Gwin Jones, of 8, Trevor Terrace, Knightsbridge—on the night of May 14th his house was broken into, and a quantity of silver stolen, value about £100—I had had charge of it eighteen years, and cleaned it myself, and knew it well—this silver is Mr. Jones's property, but there is not a quarter of it here—it had a crest on it—these spoons are not in the same condition now—I can see the crest on these sugar-tongs, but it has been smoothed down a good bit.
Cross-examined. The salvers were not silver—the plate has been in use a long time; it was his father's—the crest was quite plain—it is an ox's head.

ALICE SMITH . I live at 13, Rutford Gardens, Kensington—between 3rd and 4th July my house was entered by a key while it was being repaired—I missed a carriage clock and other articles—I have identified some of them—the total value is about £40—I have recovered about £12 worth, about a quarter of the whole.

ARTHUR GEORGE DUELLI . I live at 190, King's Road, Chelsea—I knew Hewlett's shop many years before he bought it—some years ago I sold Mr. Harwood a furnace—I went to the shop last March, and saw him there—he told me he had no use for the furnace, and I bought it and

the tongs for £2 2s.—I did not have a poker or a rake; they were missing—it was full of burnt paper, and did not appear to have been recently used; I took it away—this (the jemmy) or anything that would go between the bars would do for a poker.

p.hi: Coolidge produced a written defence, stating that she was innocent, and never taw the things till she was at the station, and that a young man met her and inked her to pawn the trousers, which she did, and he gave her a handkerchief to put round her neck, and she gave him a shilling for a waistcoat, and that she lived in the bottom part of her son's house, and never saw what he brought home.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

893.
ARTHUR JOHN HEWLETT
was further charged on two indictments for burglary and housebreaking.
NOT GUILTY .

894.
JOHN MILLS,
GEORGE MILLS , and
BETSY ANN COOLIDGE were again indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Thomas Brown, and stealing a cape and other articles, his property. Second Count, receiving the same.

FREDEBICA BROWN . I am the wife of John Thomas Brown, a tailor, of 18, Broomwood Road, Wandsworth Common—on 18th June we went away, leaving the house empty—I received a telegram, and returned on June 30th, and found the back gate and the kitchen door open—they had got in through the kitchen window, and the house was ransacked from top to bottom—these three pillow-cases, two sheets, and two nightshirts are mine.
FREDERICK BROMLEY (Police Sergeant V). On the night of 8th July I took Coolidge, and told her she would be charged with others with breaking into 9, Alma Road; she said she knew nothing about it.

JOHN WINDSOR (Police Sergeant V). On 8th July I went to 64, Etheringham Street, where the two male prisoners live, and on the bed were three pillow-slips and a sheet, and another sheet between the bed and the mattress—I told John that they formed a portion of a house breaking case at Wandsworth—he said, "I know nothing about it; I bought them in Petticoat Lane for 8s.'—I saw forty pawn-tickets in a box in Coolidge's room; one was for two sheets, pawned for 1s.—I said, "Do you know anything about these tickets?"—she said, "Yes; they all belong to me
PERCY PETERS . I produce two night-shirts pledged with me on July 1st, in the name of Jane Smithers—I do not know who she is—this is the duplicate I gave—I know Coolidge as a customer.

895.
WALTER POWELL,
Wilful and corrupt perjury.
MR. BODKIN Prosecuted, and MR. CANDY, Q. C., Defended.

GEORGE JAMES ANDREWS . I am clerk to Mr. Pritchard, the Registrar of Lambeth County-court, and one of the officers authorised to take affidavits—on 19th July Walter Powell came before me and was sworn on the Bible—I said, "Do you swear that the contents of this affidavit are true?"—he said, "Yes," and kissed the book—this (produced) is the

original summons in the action—it claims £35 and £1 1s. costs—I also produce the judgment summons referred to in the affidavit; that is the exhibit referred to in Hardman v. Furness—I also produce an application by Walter Powell for him to serve the judgment summons—it is initialled by the Registrar—one of the bailiffs of the Court usually serves the judgment summons—if he cannot be found, some person who knows him is allowed to serve it—I produce an order of Court of July 20, ordering that the hearing of the summons shall be adjourned to August 26th.

Cross-examined. I do not know Powell or Furness—this order would not be made unless efforts to serve him had been made by the officer—the original summons is endorsed, "Not served; unable to meet defendant—W. S. Gelatly. "

JOSEPH CLARK . I am a clerk at Lambeth County-court—I produce a certified extract from the books of the Court, showing proceedings in the action of Hardman v. Powell, on September 1st, 1892, signed by the Registrar, under the seal of the Court; also a similar extract under the seal of the Court in the proceedings before Judge Bristow on July 26th, on the bearing of the judgment summons—the order is "Adjourned to August 2nd, at two o'clock; notice to be given by defendant"—this order was because Powell had not the means of defence—I produce also an order of 2nd August, "Defendant to pay £39 16s. by four instalments; the first payment on 29th August"—I was in Court when the action was called on; the defendant appeared, and I administered the oath to him—a gentleman named Williams appeared for the defendant, and asked the Judge to let the case stand over, as the summons had not been served, the defendant being at Hastings—the Judge said that the defendant ought to have appeared himself, held up the affidavit, or else the clerk did, and said, "Is this your affidavit?"—he said, "Yes"—I said, "Did you serve the summons personally?"—he said, "Yes; in London Road, outside the defendant's house"—the Judge then made the order—this is the affidavit that was held up; it was attached to the summons—as soon as the case is called the papers are handed to the Judge.

WILLIAM FREDERICK GELATLY . I was acting as usher at Lambeth County-court, and heard the case called on—the defendant got into the box and was sworn—Mr. Wilson, the agent, made a statement, and the Judge said, "You have heard what the gentleman says; did you serve the summons?"—he said, "Yes"—the Judge said, "Where?"—he said, "Personally, outside his house in London Road"—the Judge said, "18 this your affidavit?"—he said, "Yes."

Cross-examined. The Judge asked him if he had personally served it; he said "Yes," and mentioned the place—about twelve or eighteen months ago I succeeded in serving Mr. Furness. and I had to serve this particular judgment summons several times—I went to the door and asked for him and was told he was not at home—I knew him, and could have served him if I had met him anywhere—the summonses were for considerable amounts; Hardman's was for £40, and there were other similar amounts—I found his wife at his house—he is supposed to be a builder—Mr. Hardman's premises are about a mile from Mr. Furness' house; Poplar Walk Road is opposite Mr. Furness' house, and anybody wanting to watch Mr. Furness' house would be able to conceal himself and see
without being Seen—the road commences near his house, and if he came out I could have come down with him with my summons.
Re-examined. I had been to Furness' house twelve months before August 2nd—there was a re-issued summons.
By MR. BODKIN. I do not think I went to the defendant's house between the day I endeavoured to serve the summons and the hearing at the County-court.

THOMAS WILSON . I live at 282, Commercial New Road, and am a certified bailiff at Lambeth County-court—I know Mr. Furness—I am not an official of the Court; I levy distresses—on August 2nd I attended the Court for Mr. Furness—a person who called himself Walter Powell went into the witness-box—I do not recognise the defendant—I saw him sworn—he said he had been sent there by Mr. Furness to say that he had not been served with the judgment summons—the Judge said, "Why is not Mr. Furness here?"—I said, "I can fetch him"—he did not come—the hearing took five or six minutes—I did not go to fetch him—Powell said he had served it personally outside the door—have known Mr. Furness about twelve months; he called at my house two or three days before July 23rd, and said that the summons was coming on on the 23rd—I went to the Court on the 23rd, and it was adjourned to August 2nd—I did not attend on any other day before August 2nd.

Cross-examined. Furness called on me at my place of business, 282, Commercial New Road; that is about a mile from his home—I am a house agent and debt collector—this is one of my circulars—before Mr. Furness went away for his holiday he consulted me about his affairs—I knew then that he was insolvent, but did not know the amount—I knew that a great many people were taking proceedings against him in the civil courts, in some stage or other—it is my practice to attend at the County-court as agent—I was present on the 26th when the case was adjourned; I had not been called upon—I was there because Mr. Furness asked me to be there—he had heard of the remand, and said would I go on the 26th, and see what was done—I have not charged him anything—his affairs had been placed in my hands, and the collection of the debts due to him, and I was to make an offer of so much in the pound—I was present on 26th July on the instructions of Mr. Furness—he did not show me the summons; he told me he had been at Hastings for some time for the benefit of his health—that was before the 26th, or I should not have gone—it may have been the 13th, but I think it was later, after the process at Lambeth Police-court was granted; I sent a notice to the creditors dated August 15th—the meeting was to take place on the 16th, and some creditors attended—the prisoner had then been committed for trial—I was present at the trial, and made an offer on the debtor's behalf of 2s. in the pound which the creditors rejected-nothing has been done—on 26th July the Court made an order for notice to be served by post on the defendant; I did not tell the Court that I represented him; I was merely a spectator—I had no brief to watch; I simply went to see what was done and report to my principal—I saw him afterwards and told him what had taken place, and he told me he had received the notice, it was delivered
next morning—I was not there to gain time—my sole message was to say that it had not been served.

Re-examined. It may have been two or three days before 26th July that Mr. Furness asked me to go to the Court to listen to what happened; it was not a fortnight—I have a list of the claims against Mr. Furness,—Mr. Hardman's is among them.

WALTER FURNESS . I am a builder—up to a fortnight ago I lived at 136, London Road, Herne Hill—I know the defendant as manager to Mr. Hardman, a builder—I used to occupy premises belonging to Mr. Hardman in Atlantic Road, for which I paid £45 a year—I used to see the defendent on the premises—I employ several men—I am learning Jeffrey the business, and he attends to it when I am away—I have some relatives at Hastings named Savage—I went to Hastings this year with my wife and family and a servant girl, and stayed from July 9th to July 21st at Mrs. Churcher's, Worthing House, Church Street, Hastings—I did not come to town at all during that time—I was not at my house in London Road on the morning of July 13, nor did I receive from the defendant that morning a judgment summons issued by Hardman against me; I was in Hastings on the 13th, and had breakfast with my wife and family, and Mrs. Churcher attended on us I saw my uncle that day at eleven o'clock—we walked on the Parade, and then dined at a restaurant, then went on the pier and went to Eastbourne by boat, and came back without landing, and at half-past five had tea at the Creamery—I was in Hastings that night and Tuesday also—I slept at Worthing House, and at 7.45 a.m. I was in bed—the first I heard of the judgment summons was the notice of adjournment which came by post—I think it was after that I saw Mr. Wilson and asked him to do something for me.

Cross-examined. I am sure this document was the first intimation I had of the judgment summons being granted—I had heard it mooted that there was a judgment summons, returnable on 26th—I told him so, but I did not attend, as I had not had the summons—the County-court bailiff had not twenty judgment summonses against me in one year—I heard from one of my men that it was the 24th—the first I heard of it was the introducing the word official—I did not think it worth while to go or send to the County-court to know whether the summons was returnable that day—I knew that personal service was required, and as I had not been personally served my interest in the matter had not commenced—my lodgings at Hastings cost £1 a week—I took a few pounds down with me—I was engaged in some building operations, and had about six labourers working—I left money with Jeffrey, a lad of nineteen, to whom I am teaching the business; it was not a cheque—he had a cheque, drawn by Mr. Smith, of Loughborough Road; that cheque was sent down to me at Hastings, endorsed by me there, and paid into my uncles account—Jeffrey had not got it when I left—he did not try to cash it, to my knowledge—the weekly wages averaged about 35s. each—Jeffrey was responsible, in my absence, to see that the work went on—if I had been in London between the 9th and the 21st I should have gone round to see how they were getting on—I got daily reports from Jeffrey—I have not got his letters; it was no use keeping them—July 12th was Tuesday—I will not swear that all this did not take place on Tuesday—if my servant says that they went to the Creamery and the illuminations on Tuesday she

is mistaken—I knew at what hour Mr. Powell said he had personally served me—I didn't sleep away from home any portion of a night while I was at Hastings—I had no latchkey—I do not know that I could he in my house in London at 7.45 a.m. and be down at Hastings at 10.50—it would take twelve minutes to walk from London Road to Loughborough Park Station, so I could not get from London Road to London Bridge at 8.5; I could not get to London Bridge under three quarters of an hour—I solemnly swear that I did not on 13th July come out of my house and cross the road, and that the prisoner did not run up to me and put his hand on the gate and prevent my getting in—I swear I did not see him outside my house that morning—I knew him perfectly well—I have come in contact with him before; he could not make a mistake about me—before July 13th an attempt to levy an execution at my house was made—I was always out, because I had work at Finsbury Park, but I slept there, and went off early to my job, and came back at night—I did not leave instructions with my wife not to say where I was, she had perfect liberty to tell anybody where I was—I do not know whether half a dozen summonses were flying about which I was trying to evade—when I went to Hastings I did not know whether a judgment summons would issue or not—there was a bill of sale on my goods, and nothing to satisfy a judgment—Mr. Harding had got my furniture for his rent—I knew that the only way I could be got at by my creditors was by a committal order, and I placed my affairs in Mr. Wilson's hands before I went—I remember the circular Mr. Wilson sent out; I am not certain whether I told him to wait before sending it out till after I had got Mr. Powell committed for trial—I knew that Mr. Powell was in the service of my creditor, the plaintiff in this action—he was acting on behalf of his master, but I understood Powell had an interest in the business—I asked him to take the premises off my hands; I did not owe him two quarters' rent at that time—I knew what the rent was at the time I took possession—I did not pay the rent; I asked him to take the premises off my hands.

Re-examined. I pay my men on Saturday, but on 9th July they were paid on Friday night, because there was a bean-feast on Saturday—I was painting the fronts of seventeen houses in Belinda Road, and one of my men acted as foreman over the others, and took their time there were only repairs at Flaxman Road—both those jobs had been started before I left—it would take me twelve minutes to get from my house to Loughborough Park Station; I go there mostly by the London, Chatham, and Dover, but I went to Hastings by the London and Brighton, and took a tourist ticket for 10s. 2d., which lasted a fortnight—I had never been to Mrs. Churcher's house before—Jeffrey slept at my house, and took his meals out—on the Tuesday evening before this Wednesday I was on the parade and the pier with me Savage and my wife; we had supper between ten and eleven, I won't be certain where—it is a fact that on July 9th and 21st I was unable to meet my debts.

ANNIE ELIZABETH FURNESS . I am the wife of the last witness—I have known the defendant about two years—on 9th July we went to Hastings with two children and a servant, and stopped at Mrs. Churcher's, Worming House—my uncle, Mr. Savage, lives there—my husband slept with toe on each of the nights we were at Hastings, and was never absent a

single night—I had breakfast with him every morning—Mrs. Churcher waited on us—on Wednesday, July 13, we had breakfast about 8.30, and went out afterwards, and met my uncle and aunt about 10.30 or 11 o'clock on the parade—we left the children on the beach and walked up and down till lunch time, when we went to Gatti's, and then went to Eastbourne by the Seagull, and returned at 5.30, and had tea at the Creamery, and about 5.10 we went on the pier, where there was a pantomime of "Whittington and his Cat" and illuminations—on 21st July I came back to London, with my husband and children—I was present at Lambeth County-court on August 2nd, and saw Mr. Wilson there; I heard the case called on, and saw the defendant go into the box—I told my husband what had happened.

Cross-examined. Gelatly has called at our house several times, but I did not know who he was—my husband was sometimes at home during the day, some gentlemen have seen him—I do not always answer the door; I have a servant, who is here—Mr. Gelatly did not tell me what lie wanted my husband for—I did not know anything about my husband's money matters; it came upon me quite as a blow—I left a servant in charge of the children—if she says this was on a Tuesday that is a mistake—we slept upstairs, not in a room opening from the sitting-room—I never missed my husband during the night—we were a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes from the station—Worthing House is in Hill Street, not facing the sea; it is by the fish market—it would take me twenty minutes to walk to the station—I daresay my husband could walk it in ten minutes—I had no knowledge of any summons till I was before the Court on August 2nd, and when these people called I had no know ledge what they called about—one of them said that Mr. Furness owed him money—my husband did not tell me what to say if people called—I told several people where I thought he was—T knew nothing till the execution was put in—I knew there was a bill of sale, and that all the furniture in the house was included in it—my husband took third claw return tickets to Hastings—I do not know whether he took a single ticket up to town.

Re-examined I saw this announcement in the newspaper of the performance on the pier, "Mr. Hunter takes his benefit on Wednesday evening next"—it was Mr. Hunter's performance we went to see on that Wednesday evening—I have no doubt that from July 9 to 21 my husband slept in the same room with me every night—I never heard before of a midnight journey to London and back; my husband never took such a journey.

FLORENCE MARSHALL . I am a servant to Mrs. Furness—I went with her and my master to Hastings on 9th July—I had charge of the children—we stayed till the 21st, and all came back together—my master was not away on any day or night between the 9th and the 21st—we all had breakfast together, and Mr. Furness was never absent from breakfast—I remember the performance on the pier on the 13th; it was a Wednesday; the pier was illuminated.

Cross-examined. I said, first, that the day was Tuesday—I am certain that the 13th was Wednesday; I have not been told so since, but I have thought of it—Mrs. Furness came down to breakfast first; she used to pour out the tea—I cannot say what time Mr. Furness came in to breakfast on the 13th, but when he came in he had some breakfast—

there was no clock in the room—I do not know that he had to meet his uncle—I slept downstairs with the children—I went to bed on the Tuesday night at 9.30, and slept all night; and he did not disturb me if he went out.

MARY CHURCHER . I live at Worthing House, Hill Street, Hastings, about a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes from Hastings Station—it is a lodging house—I have been in Hastings two years—Mr. and Mrs. Furness came to lodge with me on July 9th, and occupied a sitting-room and two bedrooms—my sister and I attended to them till they left—Mr. Furness never absented himself, to my knowledge, from July 9th to the 21st—I attended them at breakfast from 8.20 to 8.30—I never remember Mr. Furness having breakfast by himself as late as a few minutes before eleven; breakfast was always out of the room by nine o'clock.

Cross-examined. I keep no servant—they paid £1 1s. a week for their rooms—I had a deposit when they first came—I have walked to the station lots of times—my sister or I cleared away the breakfast, whichever was more ready—I do not remember whether I went on the Tuesday, Wednesday, or Thursday, but Mrs. Furness was speaking to me on the Wednesday morning as I was clearing the breakfast about going to the benefit; they were going to book tickets—I cannot swear that Mr. Furness was in the room at that conversation, but he was there when I took the breakfast in—they were the only lodgers I had—my sister is not here.
Re-examined. I did not see the benefit announced in the paper before it took place—Mr. Hunter is very well known there—I think it is an annual benefit.

JOSEPH CLARK (Re-examined). I know Hastings; I have been there year after year—I know Hill Street—you cannot walk from there to the railway station under a quarter of a hour very sharp walking, and ordinary walking it would take twenty minutes.

ALFRED HENRY SAVAGE . I live at Clyde Villas, Hastings, and have retired from business—I am the uncle of Mrs. Furness—I remember their coming to Hastings on July 9th; they stayed till the 21st—Mr. Hunter took his benefit on Wednesday, July 13th, and I met Mr. and Mrs. Furness that morning at eleven o'clock on the sea-front about six minutes' walk from Hill Street; farther from my house, but nearer to the station—we strolled about the parade and had lunch at one of the restaurants, and afterwards went on the pier with a view of attending Mr. Hunter's benefit; it was very crowded, and we went on board one of the boats and went to Eastbourne, and returned at five o'clock—Mr. Furness was in my company all that time—on the Tuesday we went to the front; they were in the place at six o'clock at tea, and about nine o'clock we left, and I went home with my wife—I never heard anything said while I was there about a visit by Mr. Furness to London.

Cross-examined. I left Mr. Furness on the Tuesday, evening on the parade, and what his movements were going to be I did not know—for all know he may have gone to London by the 9.15 train—I said before the Magistrate that I left my house at 1.0.30 on the 13th; it would take half an hour to walk to the sea-front

single night—I had breakfast with him every morning—Mrs. Churcher waited onus—on Wednesday, July 13, we had breakfast about 8.30, and went out afterwards, and met my uncle and aunt about 1U. 30 or 11 o'clock on the parade—we left the children on the beach and walked up and down till lunch-time, when we went to Gatti's, and then went to Eastbourne by the Seagull, and returned at 5.30, and had tea at the Creamery, and about 5.10 we went on the pier, where there was a pantomime of "Whittington and his Cat" and illuminations—on 21st July I came back to London, with my husband and children—I was present at Lambeth County-court on August 2nd, and saw Mr. Wilson there; I heard the case called on, and saw the defendant go into the box—I told my husband what had happened.

Cross-examined. Gelatly has called at our house several times, but I did not know who he was—my husband was sometimes at home during the day, some gentlemen have seen him—I do not always answer the door; I have a servant, who is here—Mr. Gelatly did not tell me what he wanted my husband for—I did not know anything about my husband's money matters; it came upon me quite as a blow—I left a servant in charge of the children—if she says this was on a Tuesday that is a mistake—we slept upstairs, not in a room opening from the sitting-room—I never missed my husband during the night—we were a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes from the station—Worthing House is in Hill Street, not facing the sea; it is by the fish market—it would take me twenty minutes to walk to the station—I daresay my husband could walk it in ten minutes—I had no knowledge of any summons till I was before the Court on August 2nd, and when these people called I had no knowledge what they called about—one of them said that Mr. Furness owed him money—my husband did not tell me what to say if people called—I told several people where I thought he was—I knew nothing till the execution was put in—I knew there was a bill of sale, and that all the furniture in the house was included in it—my husband took third class return tickets to Hastings—I do not know whether he took a single ticket up to town.

Re-examined I saw this announcement in the newspaper of the performance on the pier, "Mr. Hunter takes his benefit on Wednesday evening next"—it was Mr. Hunter's performance we went to see on that Wednesday evening—I have no doubt that from July 9 to 21 my husband slept in the same room with me every night—I never heard before of a midnight journey to London and back; my husband never took such a journey.

FLORENCE MARSHALL . I am a servant to Mrs. Furness—I went with her and my master to Hastings on 9th July—I had charge of the children—we stayed till the 21st, and all came back together—my master was not away on any day or night between the 9th and the 12th—we all had breakfast together, and Mr. Furness was never absent from breakfast—I remember the performance on the pier on the 13th; it was a Wednesday; the pier was illuminated.

Cross-examined. I said, first, that the day was Tuesday—I am certain that the 13th was Wednesday; I have not been told so since, but I hare thought of it—Mrs. Furness came down to breakfast first; she used to pour out the tea—I cannot say what time Mr. Furness came in to breakfast on the 13th, but when he came in he had some breakfast—

there was no clock in the room—I do not know that he had to meet his uncle—I slept downstairs with the children—I went to bed on the Tuesday night at 9.30, and slept all night; and he did not disturb me if he went out.

MARY CHURCHER . I live at Worthing House, Hill Street, Hastings, about a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes from Hastings Station—it is a lodging house—I have been in Hastings two years—Mr. and Mrs. Furness came to lodge with me on July 9th, and occupied a sitting-room and two bedrooms—my sister and I attended to them till they left—Mr. Furness never absented himself, to my knowledge, from July 9th to the 21st—I attended them at breakfast from 8.20 to 8.30—I never remember Mr. Furness having breakfast by himself as late as a few minutes before eleven; breakfast was always out of the room by nine o'clock.

Cross-examined. I keep no servant—they paid £1 1s. a week for their rooms—I had a deposit when they first came—I have walked to the station lots of times—my sister or I cleared away the breakfast, which ever was more ready—I do not remember whether I went on the Tuesday, Wednesday, or Thursday, but Mrs. Furness was speaking to me on the Wednesday morning as I was clearing the breakfast about going to the benefit; they were going to book tickets—I cannot swear that Mr. Furness was in the room at that conversation, but he was there when I took the breakfast in—they were the only lodgers I had—my sister is not here.
Re-examined, I did not see the benefit announced in the paper before it took place—Mr. Hunter is very well known there—I think: it is an annual benefit.

JOSEPH CLARK (Re-examined). I know Hastings; I have been there year after year—I know Hill Street—you cannot walk from there to the railway station under a quarter of a hour very sharp walking, and ordinary walking it would take twenty minutes.

ALFRED HENRY SAVAGE . I live at Clyde Villas, Hastings, and have retired from business—I am the uncle of Mrs. Furness—I remember their coming to Hastings on July 9th; they stayed till the 21st—Mr. Hunter took his benefit on Wednesday, July 13th, and I met Mr. and Mrs. Furness that morning at eleven o'clock on the sea-front about six minutes' walk from Hill Street; farther from my house, but nearer to the station—we strolled about the parade and had lunch at one of the restaurants, and afterwards went on the pier with a view of attending Mr. Hunter's benefit; it was very crowded, and we went on board one of the boats and went to Eastbourne, and returned at five o'clock—Mr. Furness was in my company all that time—on the Tuesday we went to the front; they were in the place at six o'clock at tea, and about nine o'clock we left, and I went home with my wife—I never heard anything said while I was there about a visit by Mr. Furness to London.

Cross-examined. I left Mr. Furness on the Tuesday, evening on the parade, and what his movements were going to be I did not know—for all know he may have gone to London by the 9.15 train—I said before the Magistrate that I left my house at 10.30 on the 13th; it would take half an hour to walk to the sea-front.
By the JURY. They left me on the parade about eight o'clock on the Tuesday night, and I have no knowledge of their movements after that.

FREDERICK JEFFREY . I am a clerk to the prosecutor, learning his business, and now live at Canterbury Road, Croydon—I was sleeping at London Road during the whole of July—I recollect Mr. Furness going away on 9th July, the day of the bean-feast—he came back on the 21st—he did not come back between the 9th and 21st—I looked after the men in his employment—I went to the men working at Flaxman Road and Belsize Road every day—he went away on Saturday, and I paid the men the next week—Mr. Furness had left me £8 or £9—I was at the County court on August 2nd, and heard part of what passed.

Cross-examined. I am eighteen years old—it is not true to say that I am the foreman—I had to get up pretty early—on Wednesday morning, 13th July, I went to the shop first—I think I was out of the house by 6.30—I had my breakfast out, but I went back at eight o'clock, because if there were any letters I was to forward them to Hastings—I had a latchkey—I did not know about a judgment summons, and did not hear the labourers talking about it—I did not find any letters when I went back—the six or eight men had a bean-feast—about four of them were constant—I got a cheque from Mr. Smith for about £6; I called on him, and got it after Mr. Furness went away—it was in respect of what he was the agent for—I kept the money till Mr. Furness came home, and handed it to him—I usually posted the letters about seven minutes to eight a.m.—I had to buy materials and pay for them.

HERBERT SIDNEY (Not examined in chief) Cross-examined. I live at 11, Blackfriars Road—I am in Mr. Furness' service—on Friday, 6th August, the prisoner sent for me, and I saw him the next day—he told me that on the morning of July 13th he tried to see Mr. Furness, but could not, and at a quarter-past eight Mr. Furness came out of his house, and he put his hand on the gate, and prevented his going in, and served the notice, and he screwed it up and put it in his pocket—he asked me whether Mr. Furness was away from home in the week the bean-feast occurred, and I said that he was away from that day till the 23rd—I was engaged on the job in Belinda Road—Jeffrey was left to see how the work was going on, and to report to his employer—I do not. know that there was a rumour current that there was a judgment summons against Mr. Furness, but the prisoner told me some weeks before, and asked me to go and see him, and I heard a little of the circumstances between him and the governor, but with regard to the judgment summons I know nothing.

By MR. BODKIN. I knew Powell about fifteen months before August—a letter was left at my house, and I went to his house; I had only been there before to work—I was working constantly at Belinda Road day after day—Mr. Furness did not come to see the work till we went for our bean-feast—I told Powell I did not know whether Furness had gone to Hastings or where he had gone—we did not know anything of his whereabouts—he asked me whether I should like to stay to breakfast; I said "No," and left.

LEOPOLD HARDMAN . I live at Brixton—the defendant is my shop assistant—Mr. Furness is a tenant of mine—he got in arrears of rent, and I was obliged to take action against him—on July 11th the prisoner

was at my place of business—I had prior to that instructed him to obtain a judgment summons, and to serve it personally—he left and returned; my instructions had not been carried out—I instructed him that evening to go again next morning; he went out, and I saw him come back at 8.30, the time of opening the shop—my instructions had not been carried out, and I sent him again that evening, Tuesday, the 12th, and he returned without having served it—I instructed him to go again next morning, and he came into my room about five o'clock to fetch the keys; I told him to take them; he did so, and left, and came back between 8.30 and nine o'clock—my instructions had then been carried out, as far as I know—Powell knew Mr. Furness well; he had constant opportunities of seeing him.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. He lived in the same house as I do—he was paid weekly—he is no relation of mine—this was considerably earlier than his usual time of getting up—he used to breakfast with me—it is half an hour's walk from my shop to London Road—I know nothing about the service except what he told me.
Re-examined. Schmidt was in my employ; he slept there on the night of July 12th.

JOSEPH SCHMIDT . I am an assistant to Mr. Hardman—I slept there on the night of July 12th—Mr. Powell did not sleep in the same portion of the shop, and he had to pass me to get out—on the Tuesday he passed me and got over my bed at six o'clock, and next day, Wednesday, at five o'clock—I knew what he was going for—he came back about 8.30—I had had breakfast at eight; he had his breakfast when he came back—he said nothing—breakfast was over, and I was going about the business of the day.

ROBERT HUTCHINSON . I am a builder—I was at work with Powell at my workshop in Tunstall Road—he was absent one morning, I could not say the date—he told me beforehand why he should not be there—he arrived about eleven o'clock—he ought to have been there at six.

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

896.
JAMES McNAMARA (22) and
DENNIS O'OONNER (24)
PLEADED GUILTY to unlawfully obtaining, from
Mary Headland, a quantity of ale and tobacco by false pretences.—
Six Months' Hard Labour each.

897.
JAMES SAUNDERS (29)
, to feloniously receiving, a pair of boots, knowing them to be stolen.
[Pleaded Guilty: See original trial image.] (See page 1384.) And

898.
ALFRED LUNN**(36)
, to burglary in the dwelling-house of
Jeffery Chappie, and stealing three coats and other articles, his property.—
[Pleaded Guilty: See original trial image.]
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

899.
MARY EVANS (32) and
GEORGE EVANS (36)
, Unlawfully uttering a counterfeit sovereign twice in the same day.

HENEY MORGAN . I am a barman at the Halfway House, 160, Battersea Park Road—on 20th August, about 11.15, the male prisoner came in and asked for a quartern of whisky in a bottle, and tendered this coin—I knew by the weight that it was bad, and showed it to Mr. "Webb.
CHARLES WEBB . I am manager of the Halfway House, which is one hundred and fifty yards from the Royal Arms—Morgan handed me this coin—I went to the prisoner and asked what it was—he said, "It is a

sovereign"—I said, "In a very few seconds I will prove that it is not" and I put it in one scale and a sovereign in the other—he said he had taken it in his wages—I gave him the coin and he left with it—I have known him sixteen years as a respectable, hard-working man, and I really thought he had taken it in his wages.

ALICE MART HARVEY . I am barmaid at the Royal Arms—on 20th August, about 11.15, the female prisoner came in and asked for a quartern of whisky in a bottle, and gave me a coin—I saw it was bad, and took it to the Landlord.

ALEXANDER JAMES AVERT . Harvey brought me this coin, which the Inspector marked in my presence, and said the female prisoner had given it to her—she said her husband gave it to her, and asked me to give it back to her and she would pay me—I refused, and sent for the police.

SOLOMON DILLS (Policeman). Mr. Avery gave the female prisoner into my custody—I asked her how she became possessed of the coin—she said, "I have been doing a bit on the crack, on the quiet, and the gentleman gave it to me, and I took it to my husband; I took it to the Halfway. House, and was told it was bad; I did not believe it, and took it to the Royal Arms and tried to change it, and was stopped"—she handed me her purse and money.

INSPECTOR LEE. The female prisoner was brought to the station and charged—she said, "Five of them were given to me by a gentleman, for what purpose I will leave you to surmise; four of them were changed through my husband, and I went to change another, and the landlord locked me up"—I took the male prisoner next morning with Tredgate and another constable—I told the prisoner his wife was in custody for attempting to pass this bad coin at another public-house—he said, "My wife and a lad next door found these things in a purse; I did not know they were wrong; Mr. Webb put a good one in the scale and this in the other scale, and said it was bad. "

FREDERICK TREDGATE (504 T). I was with the Inspector—I found six half-crowns, three florins, and three farthings—on the table I found a waistcoat—I said to the prisoner, "Is this your waistcoat?"—he said, "Tee," and in the right-hand pocket I found some coppers, and in the left this gilt shilling.
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . These three coins are Mint-struck shillings, gilt.
The prisoners' statements before the Magistrate. Mary Evans says: "Mr. Avery's evidence is not true at all." George Evans says: "I expect I took one in my wages."

MARY EVANS
GUILTY .—
Three Months' Hard Labour ,
GEORGE EVANS (who received a good character).
NOT GUILTY .

900.
JOHN BROWN (55) and
WILLIAM FREDERIOK SUM MERSBY (33)
, Robbery with violence on
Joseph Gully, and stealing £1 0s. 6d.

JOSEPH GULLY . I am a labourer, of 122, Besley Street, Walworth—on 13th August I met the prisoners in Walworth Road—we went and had a drink; I did not get very drunk; they were sparring about, and we went out of that house and into the Joiners' Arms, where I was knocked senseless—I cannot recollect anything that happened before
that, only that we went into the Olive Branch, and there was a bit of sparring, and one hand was put into my pocket—when I came to my senses I missed £1 0s. 6d.—I did not feel it taken.

JAMES BARWICK . I shall be fourteen in October—I live at 31, John Street—on Saturday, 13th August, I saw the two prisoners and two other people and Gully—Brown hit Gully, who took off his coat, and Brown hit him again and he fell senseless—Summersby came up and Brown felt in his pocket—a policeman told me to follow them, and I saw a half-sovereign and some silver in Brown's hand—they were arrested.

RICHARD MORTLOCK . I live at 21, George Street—I was with Barwick, and saw the prisoner come out of the Joiners' Arms—Brown knocked Gully down, and Summersby was helping Gully, not doing him any harm—I did not see any money, or any hand put in, his pocket.
NOT GUILTY .

901.
MARY ANN RUTTER (32)
, Stealing a watch and chain and other articles, of
Henry Wall, in his dwelling-house.

SUSAN ALICE WALL . I live at 3, Walpole Street—my husband is an invalid, and in an asylum—I had his watch, chain, and medal—I put them away on August 2nd, and did not go to the drawer again till the 27th, when they were gone—the drawer was locked, but the woodwork above it was broken, but it could not be opened without a key—on 16th August the prisoner came to the house with my lodger in a cab—I left the house, and in about ten minutes they passed me in a cab—I have seen the watch, chain, and medal since, and identified them.
Cross-examined. I only lived in the house six weeks—I have already prosecuted the other woman, my lodger, who is the prisoner's sister.
HENRY SUTTON . I am a pawnbroker's assistant, of 95, King Street, Hammersmith—on August 16th two women came; one of them pledged these articles, and the prisoner was with her.
Cross-examined. I only recognise her as standing in the shop—I had no difficulty in identifying her at the Police-court.

ELI PRITCHABD (220 V). On August 30th I went to 1, Palmerston Road, Kilburn, and I saw the prisoner there—I told her I was a constable, and should take her in custody for being concerned with her sister in stealing a watch, chain, and medal from Mortlake—she said, "I know nothing about it; I have not been at Mortlake for a long time"—I said, "Were not you at Mortlake, and did not you go to the pawnbroker's?"—she said "No"—I said, "You will have to accompany me to Barnes Police-station"—on the way she said, "I had better tell the truth; my sister came to me about a fortnight ago, we went to her room; she said, 'I have got no money, but I know where there is something I can make something with;' she went into Mrs. Wall's bedroom, and I kept watch. She came back with a watch, chain, and medal, and we went and pledged them for £1; I destroyed the ticket in the presence of my sister, because I told her if we kept it she ought get into serious trouble. "

Cross-examined. I took a note afterwards—I did not ask for any questions, she said it voluntarily—I have since heard that she is a woman of not very strong intellect—her sister pleaded guilty—the prisoner said that she had no felonious intention.
NOT GUILTY .

902.
GEORGE SMITH, (17)
, Burglary in the dwelling-house of
John Osment, and stealing a watch and chain and other articles, his property.

JOHN OSMENT . I am a licensed victualler, of 338, South Lambeth Road—on 8th May, about 10.45 p.m., my house was all locked up—I was the last person up—my drawing-room is on the ground floor—the shutters were not closed—next morning about 4.30 I heard someone ran downstairs—I went down and found the house in disorder, the back doors open, and property packed up to be taken away value £60 or £70, and among them this pair of boots which I had worn that day Sunday.

HENRY DENMAN (Detective W). I examined these premises with Inspector Barrett; an entry had been made by the drawing-room window—they had to climb up six feet and put the catch back—on May 24th I received this pair of boots from chief warder Hollingdale—I took the prisoner outside 'Wandsworth Prison, and took him to Clapham station—when he was charged he said, "Several of them have been on the game; I was pinched, and I kept the boots. "

FREDA LAWSON . I am a general servant—I was in Mr. Osment's service—on May 9th I awoke about 3.30; I did not hear any noise—I went to sleep a second time, and was awoke and saw a man in my room—I cannot swear to the prisoner, but he is very much like him—I gave an alarm.

HENRY BARRETT (Police Inspector W). I went with Denman on 9th May to the prosecutor's premises; he handed me this pair of old boots—I tried them on the prisoner, and they exactly fitted him—I asked him if they were his—he said, "No"—I took the charge—he said, "There were others in it as well as me"
ALFRED H. HOLLINGDALE . I am chief warder of Wandsworth Goal—I saw these boots taken off the prisoner's feet on 27th May—I handed them to Sergeant Kay.
JOHN OSMENT (Re-examined). I found this pair of old boots in the garden on the morning of the burglary.

Prisoner. I was in Camberwell at the time the robbery was done, had some breakfast with two labourers, and one took a pair of boots off his feet and asked me to pawn them, but they would not take them in at the pawn-shop. Next day they took the boots away, and in the afternoon they gave me some more things. I had the boots on when I was caught.
NOT GUILTY .

903.
JESSE PONTING (32)
, Carnally knowing
Charlotte Mary Ann Price, a girl between sixteen and eighteen.
NOT GUILTY .
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, OCTOBER 17TH, 1892,
